>> Yeah. Yeah.
Uh, I mean, one of the big problems with
AV sync in games is you have the game
thread is running at frame rate 60 Hz,
120 Hz, uh, if you're lucky, and then
the the audio engine is running at an
audio block rate, some 48,000 samples,
you know, few milliseconds at a time.
So, you have these two grids that you're
fighting with that you don't even think
about on a daily basis. And the game
thread is where you decide to play a
sound or not. So if you're trying to
play a sound and have it start on a
downbeat and you're doing that logic at
60 Hz, you might be late and then it
gets to the audio thread who said, "Oh,
I just started rendering." You're going
to have to wait until my next block. So
you're getting quantized to these two
grids that have nothing to do with your
goals. That's the big problem. Uh and
the way Court solves it is it's auler.
So you have to schedule ahead. You have
to give it a little bit of time, but not
much. 16th note. Um and it'll it'll
schedule ahead and it'll hold on to that
request. It'll do the math on how far in
the future that request is to have the
event you want start on the musical bar
or beat or whatever. And it'll countd
down as it renders audio buffers and
it'll say, "Okay, it's supposed to
happen 127 samples into the next audio
buffer." And the other thing to
understand about audio rendering is
there's a lot of work and vectorization
done to um leverage the fact that you
can render 48,000 samples or 2048
samples or however big your block size
is uh up front. So we don't want to
split it up just to start one sound. So
when it's time for that final buffer
where you want the onset of that sound
to start, it just runs that sound source
through a delay line so that it's it's
sample accurate and it's not doing
anything fancy compared to any regular
sound source. So that's how the game
thread to audio thread portion of of
quartz works.
>> So I'll add a little bit to that uh just
to be real clear. So sample rates are
48,000 samples a second because the
highest frequency you can hear as a
human is
>> So let's just double it.
>> Yeah. Yeah. And so the the sort of math
of sampling uh
>> for the dogs.
>> Yeah. It's the sort of fundamental
principles you need to you know have

twice of what you could possibly see or

in audio. uh rendering 48,000 samples a

naive way where you say the hardware
goes give me another sample and then you
send it to the hardware that's way too
fast so the audio would sound stuttering
it wouldn't wouldn't be able to keep up
so you render a whole bunch in a block
it's the the analog in graphics where uh
you know you don't render a pixel and
send it to hardware you render a whole
texture and a 2D grid and your your
graphics cards are designed to do
parallel processing processing of lots
of pixels at kind of relatively low
rate. I'm sorry, 60 frames a second is
nowhere near 48,000 frames a second
graphics people, but you you're
rendering uh you're rendering a slow
very slow rate texture
uh but in parallel. Audio renders a slow
rate block in serial. So the the sort of
paradigm difference is parallel versus
serial rendering. And so you're
rendering in time a block of audio and
you consume parameters from the game
thread at that block rate. So if you're
rendering at 48,000 you might be
rendering per block 512 samples or 1,024
by default. He hates it. Uh so uh you
you're consuming parameters from the
game at that rate which increases the
feeling of latency and it's also hard to
get perfect timing for something like
music. And so Quartz has this mechanism
where you can delay the request and then
it gets to the last second and it
schedules it in that block at the exact
sample that you want the sound to start
playing. And he does it with this delay
line. So you don't have to go if you
know in in the loop in the code. You're
not like if is this the right sample? Is
this the right sample? Is this the right
sample? Okay, now I do it. So it's a
little bit optimized.
